prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(2-1) mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A 80x130 square arcsec mosaic in band 3 to probe CO(2-1) line emission from cluster galaxies at z=1.58.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The main goals of this project, as discussed in the scientific justification, require that we detect CO(2-1) line emission from star-forming cluster galaxies at z=1.58 with SFR as low as 40Msun/yr (Chabrier IMF). This SFR limit corresponds to an IR luminosity L_IR ~4e+11 Lsun. Based on the observed correlation between L'_CO and L_IR up to high redshift as measured in Sargent et al. 2013, and assuming a line FWHM of ~350km/s, and a CO SLED as measured in Dannerbauer et al. 2009, we estimate our target CO(2-1) line flux as ~ 0.58mJy. We thus require an rms of ~0.12mJy in order to obtain a ~5sigma detection. We probe our target area within the cluster with a mosaic of 11 pointings covering ~80x130 square arcsec. According to the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator, with standard calibrations and wheather conditions, and 34 antennas, the required sensitivity for these observations may be reached with a total exposure time on source of ~3.5h, or ~6.4h including time on calibrators and overheads. For these spectral line observations we will use FDM. Given the angular size of our targets, we are typically interested in angular scales not larger than 2-3", and being this a detection experiment, we do not ask for particularly high angular resolution. Therefore, any configuration giving an angular resolution of ~0.5-1" (C34-4 to C34-7) will be appropriate for our purposes. On the other hand, given the crowded target field, configurations more compact than C34-2 are not the most favourable for our goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum band 7 pointings
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 23 targeted band 7 pointings to probe the continuum flux density of massive SF cluster galaxies at z=1.58, with SFR>70Msun/yr (Chabrier IMF).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
One of the goals of this proposal is the high-resolution follow-up of massive Herschel-detected starforming galaxies possibly associated with the cluster, in order to unambiguously identify their counterpart and properly determine SFR for sources which are blended at the coarse Heschel resolution. Note that high-resolution continuum observations are also very important with respect to the other component of this proposal, focusing on CO line emission, both for properly probing the correlation between CO line and continuum luminosity (and L_IR) for these sources, as well as a crucial piece of information in discriminating SFR and membership for candidate cluster galaxies, and thus ultimately in addressing the amount of star formation actually associated with massive galaxies belonging to the cluster.
In this part of the project, we target Herschel sources with SFR typically >70Msun/yr (Chabrier IMF), corresponding to an IR luminosity L_IR ~7e+11 Lsun. We estimate the observed continuum flux density at 350GHz based on far-IR templates. In order to avoid the overestimation from the "main-sequence template" (Elbaz et al. 2011), we use the appropriate SED for a main-sequence galaxy at the cluster redshift from the 2SFM modeling of Bethermin et al. 2012, based on the Magdis et al. (2012) templates. This gives an expected 350GHz flux density for our targets of ~0.8mJy. Due to the small HPBW in band 7, we individually follow up all the Herschel detections falling in the 80x130 square arcsec area which is the target of this proposal (23 pointings).
According to the ALMA OT sensitivity calculator, with standard calibrations and wheather conditions, a total bandwidth of 7.5GHz and 34 antennas, we can reach a >5sigma detection (rms<0.16mJy) in ~2' on source time per pointing, resulting in an overall total time of ~1.6h for all pointings including calibrators and overheads. For these continuum observations we will use TDM, and dual polarization.
Given the angular size of our targets, we are typically interested in angular scales not larger than 2-3", and being this a detection experiment, we do not ask for particularly high angular resolution. Therefore, any configuration more compact than C34-3, giving an angular resolution of ~0.5-1"at band 7, will be appropriate for our purposes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose an ALMA follow-up of the most distant X-ray selected galaxy cluster discovered to date, XMMUJ0044.0-2033 at z=1.58. This is among the most massive of the very distant clusters, with a total mass of ~5e+14Msun/yr already more than 9 billion years ago. In spite of its high mass and X-ray luminosity, suggesting an already relatively established structure, this cluster shares with other z > 1.5 systems galaxy population properties which testify to our approaching the formation epoch of massive cluster galaxies. Among a growing multi-wavelength data set targeting this special region in the high-redshift Universe, the deep Herschel observations of this very distant cluster probe, in an unbiased way, its massive star-forming galaxy population. The proposed ALMA observations will significantly extend the reach of the Herschel data, with their synergy providing for the first time a detailed picture of cold gas reservoirs, dust-unbiased star formation and dust in a very massive cluster environment at this redshift. These observations will thus enable a stringent test to the reversal of the SF-density relation at the highest redshifts
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: European Space Astronomy Centre (ESAC), European Space Agency
